commanders.name: Magda, Brazen Outlaw
commanders.reasoning: As a commander, this card offers a flexible and repeatable tutor that will frequently be accessible to the player, which violates WoTC's 'few tutors' clause for Bracket 2.

While Maralen's effect is symmetrical, effects like Opposition Agent effectively end the game the turn after she hits the board.

commanders.name: Chulane, Teller of Tales
commanders.reasoning: This commander is infamous for providing insane generic value into the midgame, and as such may not sit as well in Bracket 2 even with comparably weak decklists. We bias the ranking slightly to compensate.

commanders.name: Oloro, Ageless Ascetic
commanders.reasoning: Our estimate biases decks with Eminence at the helm, and Oloro is effectively an eminence commander.

commanders.name: Korvold, Fae-Cursed King
commanders.reasoning: This commander is infamous for providing insane generic value into the midgame, and as such may not sit as well in Bracket 2 even with comparably weak decklists. We bias the ranking slightly to compensate.

commanders.name: Derevi, Empyrial Tactician
commanders.reasoning: Like Yuriko, Derevi's cheat-in ability means that in brackets where effects like Cursed Totem aren't common, she is effectively impossible to keep off the board. As such, we bias the scoring slightly here.

commanders.name: Zada, Hedron Grinder
commanders.reasoning: Zada is the quintissential $50 sweat deck- we all know that a Zada deck can clear a bracket 4 game with a pipe bomb made in a cave with a box of scraps. As such, a bias is applied to decks with Zada at the helm.

commanders.name: The Gitrog Monster
commanders.reasoning: This commander is infamous for providing insane generic value into the midgame, and as such may not sit as well in Bracket 2 even with comparably weak decklists. We bias the ranking slightly to compensate.

commanders.name: Prosper, Tome-Bound
commanders.reasoning: This commander is infamous for providing insane generic value into the midgame, and as such may not sit as well in Bracket 2 even with comparably weak decklists. We bias the ranking slightly to compensate.

commanders.name: Ivy, Gleeful Spellthief
commanders.reasoning: Ivy is a pretty unique commander- while many Ivy decks don't use too many generically powerful cards, the unique options the commander provides mean that she can still be immensely threatening. As such, we include a slight bias here in an attempt to compensate.

commanders.name: Thrasios, Triton Hero
commanders.reasoning: Thrasios is the king of partners for good reason- his ability is at worst a mana sink to rectify some bad draws, and at best capable of drawing your entire deck. This, combined with partner, mean that we bias decks with these commanders slightly.

commanders.name: Tymna the Weaver
commanders.reasoning: While most partners can be generically strong, Tymna stands above her peers as a powerful early game draw engine. This, combined with partner, mean that we bias decks with these commanders slightly.
